fields.summary: S3 GET from browser that includes If-None-Match header fails

fields.description:
h2. Problem When viewing an S3 object in the web browser (i.e. html or text file), the following error occurs: {quote} This XML file does not appear to have any style information associated with it. The document tree is shown below. InternalError We encountered an internal error. Please try again. 14472b9d-fe4d-4e6c-9120-b6b0ee4a926e/0452c561-9468-4c33-adc1-76ecc8b9e39f 6aedbcb0-715c-49ad-8a97-bbf458ae2bcb {quote} It happens on *every other request*, meaning the object (or in this case the html web page) is returned correctly exactly 50% of the time. The following error appears in {{/etc/eucalyptus/cloud-output.log}} {noformat} 2015-08-27 13:09:53 WARN | CorrelationId: 941df152-c41b-4dfd-9a2d-1a6506cf3de9 Responding to client with 500 InternalError because of: java.lang.NullPointerException at com.eucalyptus.objectstorage.providers.s3.S3ProviderClient.getObjectExtended(S3ProviderClient.java:817) at com.eucalyptus.objectstorage.ObjectStorageGateway.getObjectExtended(ObjectStorageGateway.java:1222) at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor2417.invoke(Unknown Source) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606) at at org.mule.component.AbstractJavaComponent.doInvoke(AbstractJavaComponent.java:77) at org.mule.component.AbstractComponent.invokeInternal(AbstractComponent.java:126) at org.mule.component.AbstractComponent.access$000(AbstractComponent.java:61) at org.mule.component.AbstractComponent$1$1.process(AbstractComponent.java:242) at org.mule.service.processor.ServiceInternalMessageProcessor.process(ServiceInternalMessageProcessor.java:44) at org.mule.processor.AbstractInterceptingMessageProcessorBase.processNext(AbstractInterceptingMessageProcessorBase.java:106) at org.mule.interceptor.AbstractEnvelopeInterceptor.process(AbstractEnvelopeInterceptor.java:55) at org.mule.processor.AsyncInterceptingMessageProcessor.processNextTimed(AsyncInterceptingMessageProcessor.java:122) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145) at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745) {noformat} See the screenshots for details on how to reproduce the issue. h2. Cause Looking at the network trace reveals that the *Etag* of the object {{"82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4"}} is placed into the *If-None-Match* of the header of every other request, causing the internal 500 error. Here is the capture of the first request: {noformat} GET /services/objectstorage/test/itworks.html HTTP/1.1 Host: objectstorage.cdc-west-1.devlnk.net:8773 Connection: keep-alive Cache-Control: max-age=0 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/44.0.2403.157 Safari/537.36 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, sdch Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.8 HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: text/html ETag: "82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4" Last-Modified: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:04:59 GMT Content-Length: 69 Date: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:09:30 GMT x-amz-request-id: a134cf14-42d3-4160-86ba-6c81ab943e79

It Works!

{noformat} Here is the capture of the second request: {noformat} GET /services/objectstorage/test/itworks.html HTTP/1.1 Host: objectstorage.cdc-west-1.devlnk.net:8773 Connection: keep-alive Cache-Control: max-age=0 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/44.0.2403.157 Safari/537.36 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, sdch Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.8 If-None-Match: "82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4" If-Modified-Since: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:04:59 GMT HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error Content-Length: 351 Content-Type: application/xml Date: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:09:53 GMT x-amz-request-id: 941df152-c41b-4dfd-9a2d-1a6506cf3de9 InternalErrorWe encountered an internal error. Please try again.14472b9d-fe4d-4e6c-9120-b6b0ee4a926e/728be514-b70e-4013-ab91-9d7347f24b33941df152-c41b-4dfd-9a2d-1a6506cf3de9 {noformat} h2. Workaround Currently this is only broken with HTTP requests. Using HTTPS is a workaround for now.
fields.summary: 500 Internal Server Error for S3 GET requests with If-None-Match and If-Modified-Since headers

comments.body:
The failing request contains headers "If-None-Match" header with the etag value of the object that is being requested. "If-None-Match" header is a directive to (S3 interface to) return the object only if its etag is different from the value specified in the header. If thats not the case, S3 interface responds back with 304 Unmodified error - http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTObjectGET.html. From the network trace in the description it seems that OSG might be returning an incorrect return code. The failure to return the object is actually the correct behavior in this case since the conditions of the GET request are not satisfiable. 

[~dkavanagh], [~kgill] - This seems to be a GET request from the console to OSG. Can one of you check if the console is adding the two headers - "If-None-Match" and "If-Modified-Since" to the GET request

I'm unable to reproduce this in the 4.1 console.  Both HTTP and HTTPS links display an HTML and text file just fine in a browser without returning a 500 error.  Screenshot attached.

[~jgallucci32]: Could you provide more info on how the non-HTTPS links were obtained?  The Eucalyptus Management Console only generates HTTPS links for S3 objects, regardless of whether the console is access on HTTP or HTTPS.

‎The file is being accessed outside the console, and it specifically fails only when 'public' access is granted to the object. Also, it fails on the refresh (F5) of the object from the browser, not when you go to the file for the first time.

The link is derived from http://<bucket>.objectstorage.<eucadomain>‎/<object> or http://objectstorage.<eucadomain>/services/objectstorage/<bucket>/<object>. If you click only the link from the console, it includes the Access Key, Token, etc. in the request and is successful every time. This use case seems to be an issue only for publically accessible objects.

I have also tested several browsers, both desktop and mobile, and they all can reproduce the error.

John Gallucci
BAE Systems, Inc.
858.776.6820
  Original Message
From: Kamal Gill (JIRA)
Sent: Friday, August 28, 2015 2:30 PM
To: Gallucci, John (US)
Subject: [JIRA] (EUCA-11309) 500 Internal Server Error when viewing S3 objects in web browser using HTTP


*** WARNING ***
This message originates from outside our organization, either from an external partner or the internet. Consider carefully whether you should click on any links, open any attachments or reply. For additional information about Spearphishing, click here <http://intranet.ent.baesystems.com/howwework/security/spotlights/Pages/SpearphishingTips.aspx>. If you feel the email is suspicious, please follow this process. <http://intranet.ent.baesystems.com/howwework/security/spotlights/Documents/Dealing%20With%20Suspicious%20Emails.pdf>

    [ https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-11309?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel&focusedCommentId=90956#comment-90956 ]

Kamal Gill commented on EUCA-11309:
-----------------------------------

I'm unable to reproduce this in the 4.1 console.  Both HTTP and HTTPS links display an HTML and text file just fine in a browser without returning a 500 error.  Screenshot attached.

[~jgallucci32]: Could you provide more info on how the non-HTTPS links were obtained?  The Eucalyptus Management Console only generates HTTPS links for S3 objects, regardless of whether the console is access on HTTP or HTTPS.




--
This message was sent by Atlassian JIRA
(v7.0.0-OD-02-247#70102)

[~jgallucci32] - If-None-Match header might be causing one of the issues, there might be other issues around the failing refreshes. I don't think eucalyptus console adds these headers to the request which makes me wonder how they got included in the request. Can you please try accessing the object without If-None-Match and Last-Modified headers in the get request?

[~swathi], the If-None-Match and If-Modified-Since headers are standard headers from [RFC 2616 (HTTP 1.1)|http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.26] supported by most browsers.  In my case I have tested on IE 11, Chrome 44, and MS Edge, and they all display the same behavior.  First hit is good, second hit (F5 Refresh) shows Error 500.  In order to access the object without the headers, you can press *CTRL + F5* to refresh the page with cache disabled.  This indicates that it is the OSG mishandling how browsers request cached information like you mentioned in your first comment.

I'll see if I can get some network captures of the OSG tomorrow to see what else is going on.

It's starting to look more like an OSG problem. Here is the trace from the OSG showing that the S3backend properly returns a *HTTP/1.1 304 Not Modified* as expected. Here is the trace in sequence: # Client -> OSG {noformat} GET /services/objectstorage/test/itworks.html HTTP/1.1 Host: objectstorage.cdc-west-1.devlnk.net:8773 Connection: keep-alive Cache-Control: max-age=0 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8 Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1 User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/44.0.2403.157 Safari/537.36 Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, sdch Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.8 If-None-Match: "82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4" If-Modified-Since: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:04:59 GMT {noformat} # OSG -> S3backend {noformat} GET /14472b9d-fe4d-4e6c-9120-b6b0ee4a926e/728be514-b70e-4013-ab91-9d7347f24b33 HTTP/1.1 Host: s3backend.devlnk.net If-Modified-Since: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:04:59 GMT Authorization: AWS svc_eucalyptus:************************* Date: Mon, 31 Aug 2015 17:15:39 GMT User-Agent: aws-sdk-java/1.7.1 Linux/2.6.32-573.1.1.el6.x86_64 OpenJDK_64-Bit_Server_VM/24.85-b03/1.7.0_85 If-None-Match: "82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4" Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=utf-8 Connection: Keep-Alive {noformat} # S3backend -> OSG {noformat} HTTP/1.1 304 Not Modified Content-Length: 0 x-amz-id-2: txd8ee5d1cb1c343ee970bc-0055e48bbb Last-Modified: Thu, 27 Aug 2015 20:05:00 GMT ETag: "82a8797af2e435d83f3e0fd0dcfe19c4" x-amz-request-id: txd8ee5d1cb1c343ee970bc-0055e48bbb Content-Type: application/octet-stream X-Trans-Id: txd8ee5d1cb1c343ee970bc-0055e48bbb Date: Mon, 31 Aug 2015 17:15:39 GMT Connection: keep-alive {noformat} # OSG -> Client {noformat} HTTP/1.1 500 Internal Server Error Content-Length: 351 Content-Type: application/xml Date: Mon, 31 Aug 2015 17:15:39 GMT x-amz-request-id: ca149979-4a1a-4586-ad96-03bf95a50ea7 InternalErrorWe encountered an internal error. Please try again.14472b9d-fe4d-4e6c-9120-b6b0ee4a926e/728be514-b70e-4013-ab91-9d7347f24b33ca149979-4a1a-4586-ad96-03bf95a50ea7 {noformat}

[~jgallucci32] - OSG behavior to *not* return object content is correct as per S3 spec. OSG return code, 500 Internal Server Error, is incorrect. Object data should be returned by OSG only if the etag specified using If-No-Match header does *not* match the object etag. In your case, these etags match . The discrepancy in the return code is definitely a bug as I mentioned in my first comment. 

Snippet from S3 doc - http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTObjectGET.html

||Name||Description||
|If-None-Match|Return the object only if its entity tag (ETag) is different from the one specified; otherwise, return a 304 (not modified).
Type: String
Default: None|

Regardless of the browser, this request to OSG or S3 will not fetch the object data. The response from OSG should have been 304 Unmodified. Is this what you are expecting?

I looked further into why a client might include If-No-Match header. It sounds like the client may have a cached copy of the object content. When the client wants to retrieve the same URL, it may include If-No-Match header with etag of the cached content. If the object etag is the same as specified in the If-No-Match header, server would respond with 304 Unmodified response indicating to the client that its cached copy is still current. The server sends entire object content only when the etags don't match. 

In the above case, OSG/server's 500 internal error response might be impacting the browser's/client's ability to display object content when "If-No-Match" header is included in the GET Request. As I mentioned before, the incorrect return code is a bug and should be fixed. I do have a few questions around client caching -  is it size bound, and what happens when the object data is not found in the cache but client receives a 304 Unmodifed response from server

[~swathi], yes that is a reasonable approach. The original intent was to push those hash-matches to the backend where the content actually is to ensure that it is as accurate as possible, but since our objects are unique and we never overwrite the only case where they don't match would be in a corruption-in-flight scenario.

Steps to verify fix

# Start with a bucket in OSG. Assign public-read canned ACL to both bucket and object at the time of creation or later for ease with testing from a browser (credentials can be skipped). 
# Upload an object with some html content (I used the example in the description) along with the Content-Type text/html header (directs the browser to display the object content as a web page rather than just download the object)

Verify from browser - (I used Chrome)
# Monitor the network traffic using ngrep or any other tool either on the OSG or on the host accessing the object. 
# Access the URL of the object from the browser and verify that html object content is displayed. 
# Verify that network traffic contains a corresponding request and response. The response should contain the object content and the HTTP status should be 200 OK
# Refresh the browser and verify that the html object content continues to be displayed
# Verify that network traffic contains a corresponding request and response. The request may contain "If-None-Match" and "If-Modified-Since" headers in which case the response should not contain any object data and the HTTP status should be 304 Not Modified

Verified. Not seeing this issue anymore. Tried several download from browser and command line. Not seeing any failure in either cases.

  006-98814..If-None-Match: "709e13d1e82e96587b2d6caa659729d3"..If-Modified-Since: Sat, 19 Sep 2015 14:40:28 GMT....
